data.name: Caesar's Cipher
data.description:
Description

In cryptography, a Caesar's cipher, is one of the simplest and most widely known encryption techniques. It is a type of substitution cipher in which each letter in the plaintext is replaced by a letter some fixed number of positions down the alphabet. For example, with a left shift of 3, D would be replaced by A, E would become B, and so on. The method is named after Julius Caesar, who used it in his private correspondence. The transformation can be represented by aligning two alphabets; the cipher alphabet is the plain alphabet rotated left or right by some number of positions. For instance, here is a Caesar cipher using a left rotation of three places, equivalent to a right shift of 23 (the shift parameter is used as the key): Plain: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ
Cipher: XYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVW

Your Task

  • Create a class called CaesarCipher with two methods: encrypt and decrypt, which one of those two methods should receive three arguments: a text to be decrypted/encrypted, a way of shift (right/left) and a number of shifts.
  • You should ignore punctuactions and other chars (just for simplicity), but don't forget to give back white spaces.

Examples:

encrypt("computer", "left", 7) #vhfinmxk
decrypt("vhfinmxk", "left", 7) #computer

encrypt("i am from brazil", "left", 10) #b tf ykhf uktsbe
decrypt("b tf ykhf uktsbe", "left", 10) #i am from brazil
